article: Earlier this morning I e-mailed an old friend, Mark. We have been out of touch for 12- years, but the _ is a wonderful thing. Finding his e-mail address _ less than a minute. He is working on his doctoral paper in western America. Mark and I met at a summer _ that we both attended. I went every year from the time I was 8- or 9- until I was 15. I don t _ exactly, but I think Mark was there for as many years as I was. We lived close to each other and _ saw each other around the campsite, but not often. Mostly we stayed together for a week or two in the _ and wrote letters back and forth during the rest of the first few years. I still have all of his letters in a box somewhere. I come across them occasionally and _ to sit down and read through them, but I never have. He was a _ and precious friend to me, and I am deeply _ that we have drifted so far apart. Mark was a very kind and incredibly bright and funny _ . He loved Monty Python I mean he was a fanatic, and could _ entire movies from memory. He was one of those kids who _ such a unique and powerful mind _ they never quite fit into the main stream of life. _ Mark, who I believe realized that, never seemed to care about it. When I knew that Mark was working on his _ (on a highly intellectual and fairly mysterious and difficult topic), I thought, Well yes, of course. He is just where I would _ him to be. I wonder if he will write me back. I wonder if he will be _ by where I am. I wonder whether he and I can be _ again, or whether these years have left us with _ in common. I wonder whether he can ever be the man I _ , or only remain the boy I knew.
